title: PE Daily: Spring Hill Nabs $151 Million | Bain Capital Backs Mixpanel | Tim Draper's ESG Style | Equinox Bags $255 Million in Bridge Financing
text:
All that and much more is summarized and linked for you below, so please dive in...

Today's Top Stories

Spring Lane Capital has raised $151 million so far for its second fund focused on sustainable infrastructure, just as the private-equity firm signed two new investments from its previous fund, Luis Garcia reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. The firm, based in Boston, said it has held a first close for its second fund, landing it a little less than halfway toward its $400 million goal.

Bain Capital's technology-focused strategy has invested $200 million in Mixpanel Inc., valuing the provider of product analytics systems at $1.05 billion, Luis Garcia reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. San Francisco-based Mixpanel's products are used to evaluate how consumers interact with client apps and websites. Mixpanel's customers include ride-sharing company Uber Technologies Inc., travel-site operator Expedia Group Inc. and internet job-search platform Indeed Inc.

Tim Draper's eponymous firm has raised a $230 million fund, Draper Associates VI, to back startups that the billionaire investor thinks will have a positive impact on the world, Yuliya Chernova reports for WSJ Pro Venture Capital. "We've been doing ESG forever," said Mr. Draper, founder and managing partner of Draper Associates, referring to environmental, social and governance investing. Mr. Draper said growing efforts by limited partners and regulators to measure and constrain investment firms to specific ESG criteria are wrongheaded. Draper Associates doesn't use specific criteria to measure its past investments or evaluate new ones, he said. ESG-related investment decisions are based on Mr. Draper's evaluation of the startups' impact on the world.

Private-equity-backed gym company Equinox Group LLC has received $255 million in new financing commitments from lenders and owners, Alexander Saeedy and Alexander Gladstone report for WSJ Pro Bankruptcy, citing people familiar with the matter. The company's backers include L Catterton, real-estate firm Related Cos. and some of its executives. The financing will provide Equinox with a bridge as it explores a potential transaction with a special-purpose acquisition company, the people said.

Upcoming Pro Event

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on November 17. The program includes a discussion on sustainability in private markets with Megan Starr, global head of impact at Carlyle Group Inc. Register here.

Big Number

$147.9 Billion

The amount raised by 542 blank-check companies through IPOs this year as of Tuesday, more than twice the number that went public in all of last year, according to data provider SPAC Research

Deals

TPG Capital and Symphony Ventures, the investment fund of professional golfer Rory McIlroy, have agreed to back a significant investment in Troon Golf LLC, a Scottsdale, Ariz.-based provider of golf and club-related leisure and hospitality services. Private-equity firm Leonard Green & Partners, which backed Troon in 2017, will retain a significant stake in the company, which offers operational, management, and advisory services to more than 620 golf and leisure facilities around the world, according to a press release.

Durational Capital Management is taking private mattress maker Casper Sleep Inc. at $6.90 per share under an agreement announced Monday. The deal represents a 94% premium to the stock's closing price on Friday and gives the New York-based company an equity value of about $286 million. Casper shares soared $3.14, or 88%, to close at $6.69.

A group of airlines backed by p​rivate-equity firm Indigo Partners has ordered 255 narrow-body planes from Airbus SE, Benjamin Katz reports for The Wall Street Journal. The airliners, all variants of an A321 model, will be delivered over several years, according to Airbus Chief Commercial Officer Christian Scherer. Reuters reported that Indigo led negotiations for the deal, which could be worth as much as $32 billion before discounts.

Global Infrastructure Partners has agreed to buy a 49% non-operating stake in the Pluto Train 2 joint venture from Woodside Petroleum Ltd. in Australia. The $5.6 billion venture is part of the Scarborough liquefied natural gas project. As part of the deal, GIP is expected to invest as much as about $835 million in addition to its 49% of the construction costs of the LNG project.

KKR & Co. has agreed to acquire a minority stake in Beacon Pointe LLC, providing an exit for Abry Partners., which initially backed the company last year. The growth investment is intended to help the registered investment adviser acquire technology and expand nationwide. The Newport Beach, Calif.-based business has more than $20 billion in assets under management and operates from 27 offices around the U.S.

Eurazeo and existing investor Leeds Equity Partners in acquiring a majority stake of training resources provider Scaled Agile Inc., joining management in the $300 million investment. The Boulder, Colo.-based company provides training, content and toolkits to help businesses become more agile in responding to changes in their markets.

Y Combinator Continuity is leading a $201 million investment in small business software company Podium Corp Inc., joined by investors that include Durable Capital Partners, Summit Partners and Accel. The Lehi, Utah-based company offers customer communications and payments processing systems geared to smaller companies that operate mainly in local communities.

Wynnchurch Capital has acquired specialty-equipment provider Owen Equipment Co. from CenterGate Capital. The Vancouver, Wash.-based company specializes in renting machinery used for maintenance of municipal sewer systems, excavating and street cleaning, among other tasks.

Great Hill Partners is investing in consumer insights provider Prodege LLC. The growth investment firm will deliver a majority stake in the El Segundo, Calif.-based company, according to a news release.

TSG Consumer Partners has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Super Star Car Wash, investing alongside management of the Phoenix-based chain, according to a news release. The business operates in 35 locations, including in Arizona and California.

Felicitas Global Partners is investing $22 million in risk-intelligence company Intelligo, whose legal name is IGMR Research Ltd. The Israeli company provides due diligence services and background checks for clients, who include Felicitas.

Apollo Global Management Inc. and Wecken & Cie. are reviewing strategic options for portfolio company Demire Deutsche Mittelstand Real Estate AG, according to a news release. Apollo first backed the business in 2018 while Wecken initially invested in 2015. Together they hold a controlling stake in the commercial real estate investment company, which is based in Langen, Germany and has more than €1.6 billion, or about $1.82 billion, in assets.

Assured Healthcare Partners is backing Oklahoma medical practice Cardiovascular Health Clinic, which is in turn setting up Cardiovascular Health Partners to expand in central and southern states, according to an emailed news release. The physician-led clinic currently operates from 11 locations in the Sooner State.

SPAC Track

Skincare startup Obagi Global Holdings Ltd. and makeup brand Milk Makeup LLC are merging with Waldencast Acquisition Corp., a special-purpose acquisition company founded by two former L'Oréal executives in a deal that values the combined business at roughly $1.2 billion, Corrie Driebusch reports for The Wall Street Journal. Milk Makeup is a vegan makeup brand that is sold at Sephora, among other retailers. Obagi's products are aimed at minimizing the appearance of sun damage, aging and acne, and are primarily available through dermatologists and other professionals.

A Motive Partners-backed blank check company has registered to raise $250 million through an initial public offering of shares with an eye toward acquiring a financial services or software company in North America or Europe, a regulatory filing shows. Motive Partners had about $2.4 billion in regulatory assets under management at the end of September, according to the filing. The special-purpose acquisition company is led by Motive Partners executives Rob Heyvaert and Jeff Yabuki.

Exits

Prelude Growth Partners has sold its stake in Brazilian-inspired skincare brand Sol de Janeiro to L'Occitane International SA, which said it is acquiring an 83% indirect equity stake in the company at a $450 million valuation. The skincare brand, which was initially backed by Prelude in 2019, will become a majority owned subsidiary of L'Occitane.

Dominus Capital has agreed to sell Cincinnati Fan & Ventilator Co. to publicly traded SPX Corp. Mason, Ohio-based Cincinnati Fan offers equipment used in heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems. New York-based Dominus initially backed the company in June 2013, according to S&P Global Capital IQ data.

Funds

Steve Cohen's Point72 Asset Management has closed on $600 million for its first private equity fund, Point72 Hyperscale LP, barely seven months after starting fundraising for the vehicle in March. The Stamford, Conn., firm run by the hedge fund maestro says on its website that the Hyperscale fund invests in companies with the potential to be transformed through the application of artificial intelligence technology. On Monday, Point72 named Dan Gwak, managing partner of Point72 Private Investments, and Sri Chandrasekar, managing partner of Point72 Ventures, as managing partners of the Hyperscale fund. Both previously co-led Point72 Ventures investments. The fund represents a tiny portion of the firm's overall regulated assets of nearly $117.54 billion as of Dec. 31, 2020.

Financial services focused Lightyear Capital has wrapped up fundraising for its Lightyear Fund V LP, collecting approximately $1.6 billion in capital for the vehicle, including a sponsor commitment. Investors include the Los Angeles County Employees Retirement Association, which pledged as much as $100 million in June, according to the WSJ Pro Private Equity LP Commitments database. Lightyear had set a $1.25 billion target for the new fund and said it is around 63% bigger than its predecessor.

European healthcare firm G Square Healthcare Private Equity is seeking €800 million, the equivalent of $915.6 million, for G Square Capital IV LP, a regulatory filing indicates. G Square, which targets buyouts and growth investments in European healthcare companies, closed G Square Capital III LP at its €500 million hard cap, according to an announcement from placement agent Asante Capital Group.

People

Valor Equity Partners announced several promotions, including for Jonathan Shulkin, whom it has promoted to co-president of the firm. Mr. Shulkin has been with Valor since 1998. The firm also promoted Christopher Murphy, who joined in 2011 and Bradley Sheftel, who joined in 2005, to partner.

One Rock Capital Partners has added Adam Kuritzky as an operating partner to assess sales and marketing strategies at target companies, according to an emailed news release. Mr. Kuritzky was most recently executive vice president of sales and marketing in North America at Proactis Holdings Ltd.

Industry News

Insurers plan to increase their investment allocations to private markets over the next few years, BlackRock Inc. said, citing a survey of 362 insurance company executives across 26 markets whose employers control $27 trillion in investable assets. The respondents indicated the average private market allocation would rise to about 14% by 2023 from 11% this year.

A real estate company whose backers include Carlyle Group Inc. and the asset management arm of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. plans an initial public offering of shares, a regulatory filing shows. Lake Como, N.J.-based Four Springs Capital Trust didn't specify how many shares it plans to sell or at what price.

Oppenheimer & Co. has set up a fund placement and advisory group, led by Tanya McHale, as a managing director based in London, and several members of her team from MVision Private Equity Advisers, according to a news release. Ms. McHale was a managing director with MVision, which she joined in 2001.

Data-center companies CyrusOne and CoreSite Realty are being acquired in two separate, multibillion deals that highlight that digital-infrastructure assets can be attractive for a range of buyers, Adrià Calatayud writes for Dow Jones Newswires. Merger-and-acquisition activity remains hot in a sector that has seen surging demand but in which several players trade at valuations that are significantly below those implied by the price tags of recent deals. KKR & Co. and Global Infrastructure Partners agreed to buy CyrusOne for $15 billion, including debt, valuing the company at 12.6 times forecasts for sales this year, according to FactSet data. Meanwhile, wireless infrastructure operator American Tower's deal to acquire CoreSite for about $10.1 billion, including debt, values the target at 15.5 times a FactSet-provided consensus for 2021 sales.

StepStone Group Inc. shareholders are planning to sell 4.5 million shares of the firm's class A stock in a secondary offering, and some of the stock could include options for additional purchases of as much as 675,000 more shares, according to a news release. The firm didn't name the selling investors, who will receive all of the sale proceeds.
